                        IntroductionRoot-zone soil moisture (RZSM) is an essential climate variable which influences water and energy cycles and regulates thermodynamic exchanges between land and atmosphere, thereby influencing regional weather and climate conditions1,2,3. Excessive RZSM drying, also known as drought, have great socio-environmental impacts related to food security, forestry, human health, environmental sustainability, or biological community structure4,5,6,7. RZSM influences both land surface and atmospheric processes through mass and energy exchanges, and its variability can be influenced by regional seasonality, internal atmospheric variability from climate oscillations, or human-induced through anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions or land cover change8,9,10. Given its vital importance for controlling land-atmospheric feedbacks, regulating water and energy processes, and determining extreme events such as droughts and heat waves, skillful RZSM forecasts at long leads are crucial for drought management, climate adaptation, mitigation, and decision making11,12,13.Previous studies have consistently identified limited subseasonal forecast skill beyond two weeks (>14 days) in current dynamic forecast systems and land surface models, including but not limited to: Noah-MP, Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF), Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC), Global Ensemble Forecast System (GEFS), and subseasonal-to-seasonal European Center for Medium Range Weather (S2S ECMWF)13,14,15,16,17,18,19,20. The subseasonal time scales ranges between ~14–60 days (~2–9 weeks), and low skill within models has been attributed to several factors, including unskillful precipitation forecasts, imperfect model parameterizations, initialization biases, and cumulative error growth associated with stochastic processes13,21. To increase dynamic models (DM) forecast reliability and reduce model biases, post-processing bias-correction techniques are applied to DM forecasts with respect to observations (or reanalysis), which have improved subseasonal forecast skill of temperature, precipitation, windspeed, and organized motion associated with the Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO)22,23,24,25. While bias correction can improve forecasts of mean conditions, substantial challenges remain in predicting extreme events, as bias-corrected forecasts often show limited skill beyond two weeks26.RZSM has a memory in which dry or wet anomalies, relative to the climatological mean, decay slowly for time periods between days to months and enhance land-atmosphere feedbacks through radiative and mass exchanges27,28,29. Soil moisture memory (SMM) varies across geographic regions, seasons, and soil depths, and is influenced by dynamic factors such as solar radiation, vegetation, and precipitation, as well as static factors like slope and soil texture30. While SMM can be a potential source of subseasonal predictability, previous studies have robustly identified that the prediction skill of dry extremes of RZSM is still limited beyond two weeks using either DMs, hybrid statistical-DMs, or machine learning methods13,19,26,30. This low predictability can be attributed to large errors in precipitation forecasts, which affect root zone soil moisture (RZSM) through well-known processes such as infiltration and recharge, as well as to poor representation of precipitation in computing dynamic mass and energy fluxes. To improve subseasonal RZSM predictability beyond current land surface models that rely on error-prone precipitation forecasts, novel methods are needed to overcome this limitation.Deep learning (DL) has the strength of learning complex systems by automatic extraction of spatial-temporal features31. By directly learning from historical reanalysis data, DL has achieved notable successes in ten-day medium-range weather predictions32,33, five-day extreme flood predictions34, and seasonal predictions of El Nino South Oscillation35 (ENSO), all showing improved performance compared to state-of-the-art DMs. Recent studies have also developed DL models for subseasonal predictions of atmospheric variables, while the method did not outperform state-of-the-art DMs, particularly at shorter leads (< 10 days)36. Due to SMM and improved medium-range weather prediction, DL has a great potential to skillfully predict subseasonal soil moisture and droughts beyond two weeks.Few studies to date have explored the potential of deep learning (DL) for subseasonal prediction of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) and drought. In addition, DL-based post-processing for bias correction of spatial RZSM forecasts remains largely unexplored. Here, we present a novel hybrid approach that skillfully predicts subseasonal RZSM and droughts by combining a recursive DL model (namely RISE-UNet) with state-of-the-art dynamic models (DMs). We investigate whether DL models trained on publicly available data can provide accurate long-lead predictions at subseasonal timescales and whether hybrid DL-DM models outperform reanalysis-driven DL models, DL- or statistically post-processed DMs, and the original DMs themselves. To test this, we designed a set of experiments including: hybrid DL-DM models that use inputs from DM reforecasts and reanalysis; DL- or statistically post-processed DMs that apply bias correction to DM outputs; and DL models trained on reanalysis data alone. All models are trained to predict RZSM reanalysis as the target variable. Given the global availability of training data, our approach can be implemented in other regions to support skillful subseasonal forecasting of RZSM and drought. Moreover, due to the central role of soil moisture in subseasonal-to-seasonal predictability, this framework could be extended to improve forecasts of other climate extremes, such as heavy precipitation and heatwaves, potentially benefiting water resources drought response, agriculture, urban planning, and ecosystem management.ResultsWeekly soil moisture forecast skill and feature importanceIn this study, our DL model, namely the residual inception squeeze-and-excitation (RISE) UNet + + (RISE-UNet, see Methodology), takes designed inputs and learns complex mapping functions between input variables and the RZSM forecast target (Fig. 1 and Supplementary Table S1). RISE-Unet accepts an arbitrary number of input predictors (channels) from both reanalysis at weekly lags and reforecast at forecast leads, and passes weighted convolution kernels across each channel to produce intermediate predictions, which are concatenated. Additional convolution kernels are passed along all intermediate predictions, and the image size is reduced through pooling operations, which allow different representations of the data to be computed within a more restricted field space, allowing the model to identify relevant features at different scales. These intermediate results are concatenated again, and the convolution/pooling process repeats until a minimal image size is reached (in our instance, a 48 × 96 pixel image is reduced to a 6 × 12 pixel image). Once the terminal size is reached, intermediate predictions are upscaled until the original image size is reached. For the RISE-Unet, three separate predictions are computed and the loss function applied over each one independently, with the goal of the model to reduce the aggregated loss of all three predictions.Fig. 1: The model architecture and experimental design.A Experimental design and model inputs. B RISE-UNet deep learning model architecture; C root zone soil moisture (RZSM) output for weekly leads 1–5. In the experiments, reanalysis-driven deep learning models (DL) only take reanalysis as inputs; combined DL and dynamic models (DL-DM) take both reanalysis and dynamic model forecasts; bias-corrected DM models (DM-BC_DL) only take RZSM from DM as inputs (see Supplementary Table S1 for more information). For DL-DM models, both recursive and non-recursive forecasts were made. For recursive DL-DM models, a forecast is made by recursively including the previous weeks’ RZSM prediction as an input feature. Deep learning is constructed based on a residual, inception, squeeze-and-excitation UNet + + architecture (RISE-UNet). As a comparison, DM is also bias corrected using ensemble model output statistics (DM-BC_EMOS).Full size imageWe trained the model separately for each week, lead 1–5 and verified skill results against the physically-based GLEAM reanalysis (see Methodology). For clarification, skill results are obtained for each forecast week lead made at weekly intervals across the calendar year/season for the two-year period 2018-2019. Results consistently indicate that both DL-DM and DL models show superior performance compared to DM, DM-BC_DL, and ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) (Fig. 2A, B). For week lead 3, both DL-DM and DL models achieve the highest average anomaly correlation coefficient [ACC] of ~0.60 (an increase of ~66% over DM forecasts EMOS) and the lowest average CRPS of ~0.015 (>27% improvement) across the contiguous United States (CONUS). Hybrid DL-DM and reanalysis-driven DL models consistently outperform EMOS postprocessed DM forecasts for all leads in ACC skill but only show an improvement in the CRPS at leads 3-4. DL-DM and DL models exhibit similar skill across all leads which can be the direct result of the model(s) converging on similar weights during the training process, additionally the models within scenarios are averaged across many experiments as well as across CONUS which can diminish the variability. Spatial differences between the DL experiment 24 (EX24) and the DL-DM experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (EX29_G) identify that variability in skill occurs across the entire region, albeit differences may be minimal (Fig. 2C, D). EX29_G mostly shows higher ACC than EX24 except in some of the eastern regions (Fig. 2D). EX29_G also consistently shows better CRPS than EX24 over all of CONUS, suggesting higher ensemble forecast skill (Fig. 2D). While multi-model ensemble is commonly used to increase forecast skill through leveraging the strengths of each model forecast, we identified that this method did not considerably increase ACC skill when combining ECMWF and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S1).Fig. 2: Overall forecast performance of root zone soil moisture anomalies for different model runs in the contiguous United States.A Anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) and (B) Continuous Ranked Probability score (CRPS) for weekly leads 1–4 averaged over testing years 2018-2019 for different scenarios and dynamic models. Different lines represent different scenarios (described in Supplementary Table S1). In the legend, the number in parentheses is the total number of runs (either experimental runs or dynamic model reforecast runs) within each scenario. The lines displayed are averaged over both the contiguous United States and all model runs within each scenario; additionally, we have averaged over both ECMWF and GEFSv12 model runs (NWP). C Lead week 3 ACC of the combined DL and dynamic model (DL-DM) experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (EX29_G), a reanalysis-driven deep learning (DL) experiment (EX24), and the difference between them, with higher values indicating that EX29_G is more skillful than EX24. D Lead week 3 CRPS of EX29_G, EX24, and the difference between them, with lower values indicating that EX29_G is more skillful than EX24.Full size imageTo identify how input variables influence RZSM forecasts, we conducted a permutation feature importance test on each experimental run (see Methods). We found the most influential predictor for week 3 was GLEAM RZSM reanalysis input at weekly lag 1 (Fig. 3). The ACC values begin to decrease more rapidly after EXP25 (which contained no reanalysis atmospheric predictors). Subsequent experiments after EX25 in Fig. 3 included reanalysis atmospheric predictors and lower skill may be due to a combination of a.) diminished effects of previous atmospheric conditions at longer leads (low signal-to-noise ratio), b.) evolving land-surface conditions (precipitation and other hydrometeorological processes) during the three-week forecasts which are more impactful on RZSM variability or c.) inclusion of too many predictors which inhibits model learning through overfitting. Specifically, research has identified that increasing the number of inputs in a neural network can create a less robust model prone to overfitting and is unable to generalize to out-of-training samples37.Fig. 3: Permutation feature importance test with mean absolute error (MAE) and anomaly correlation (ACC) values averaged over the contiguous United States during the testing period 2018-2019 for forecast lead week 3.Each of the 29 experiments is labeled on the horizontal axis and is color-coded as purple for deep learning (DL) models, as blue for combined DL and dynamic models (DL-DM), and as green for bias-corrected DM models (DM-BC_DL). Average MAE across all RISE-UNet deep learning model experiments are presented in the color bar, with higher MAE values indicating that the input has a larger influence on the final prediction (see Methods for more information on permutation feature importance test). ACC of GEFSv12, ECMWF, and ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) are also provided. We selected the EMOS experiment with the highest skill out of our four tests. The red dots show the average ACC value for each experiment on the right vertical axis. Each input is labeled on the left-hand of the vertical axis, which is named as variable abbreviation_data source_lead or lag_the number of weeks (e.g., z200_obs_lag_Wk_1-3 is geopotential height from observations (reanalysis) over lag weeks 1–3) (see Supplementary Table S2 for more information on abbreviations). Inputs which have been averaged over multiple weeks are indicated by the number of weeks listed (e.g., z200_obs_lag_Wk_1-3 will have MAE values averaged over lag weeks 1–3).Full size imageSHAP values were computed for week lead 1 prediction to further estimate each input feature’s contribution to the final model prediction (see “Methods”). Using GEFSv12 as the forecast, it was observed that the most influential features impacting model outputs included GLEAM RZSM at week lag 1 as the most influential feature, followed by ERA5 tmax at week lag 1, GEFSv12 reforecast at week lead 1, GLEAM RZSM at week lag 2, and geopotential height (z200) from both ERA5 and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S2). The higher density of SHAP values for GLEAM RZSM week lag 1, which corresponds with negative SHAP values, indicates that wetter soil conditions will lead to a drying of soils in the predicted RZSM. While this may seem counterintuitive, it is probable that the model has learned that saturated conditions lead to future drying. GLEAM RZSM at week lag 1 also identifies that wetter soils can increase the predicted RZSM output, as seen with a slightly lower density of positive SHAP values. ERA5 tmax at week lag 1 identifies that lower temperature values lead to an increase in saturation in predicted RZSM. Z200 results from both ERA5 and GEFSv12 identify that below normal heights, associated with troughs, lead to an increase in RZSM predicted values (towards wetness) as observed with a slightly higher density of values with positive SHAP. These results were identified to be robust across five different random seeds, which details low variability between different SHAP runs (Supplementary Fig. S3).The best performing model runs included only inputs from observation RZSM and/or recursive RZSM predictions (Fig. 3). The highest skill model at week 3 (EXP29) contains inputs of only lagged RZSM reanalysis and recursive RZSM predictions. While this set of inputs is highly similar to EX18, the recursive RZSM predictions from weeks 1-2 within EX29 come from models which were trained on only week 1 lag of reanalysis atmospheric conditions and short-lead DM atmospheric forecasts (weeks 1-2); therefore, it is likely that this hybrid model EX29 retains the important atmospheric signals embedded within the recursive RZSM predictions in which it is trained (Supplementary Table S1). For clarity, EXP29 will be named as either DL-DM_G (trained on GEFSv12 reforecast and other data) or DL-DM_E (trained on ECMWF reforecast and other data). Hereafter, we refer ECMWF reforecast as ECMWF. It should be noted that predictions and subsequent verification metrics from DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E are highly similar; therefore, we only present one model within each figure.We evaluate the spatial distribution of skill between DL-DM_G, EMOS, and GEFSv12 (Fig. 4). For CONUS at week lead 3, a high ACC score is achieved with the DL-DM model in many regions (DL-DM_G; ACC >0.7), with both DL-DM_G being significantly better than GEFSv12 and EMOS in the Central, Northwest, and Southeast US. DL-DM models can attain ACC >0.6 over 58% of CONUS when compared to EMOS or GEFSv12, having only ~13%. The worse performing region(s) across all models are the Mississippi and Ohio Valley regions. An assessment of seasonal variability displays that months December-February (DJF) contribute most to the overall skill for week leads 3-4 (~0.80 ACC), followed by months June-August (JJA) with ACC between 0.60-0.65, September-November (SON) with ACC between 0.50-0.60, and the lowest average skill is in March-May (MAM) with ACC between 0.47–0.51 (Supplementary Fig. S4). The KGE metric demonstrates that both DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E are better calibrated when compared to raw reforecasts for each season with >70% of grid cells have a positive KGE value as compared ECMWF and GEFSv12 (Supplementary Fig. S5). ACC skill based on the most recent GLEAM RZSM input across CONUS displays that wetter conditions lead to a more skillful forecast at weekly leads 3-4 in the Western and Northern High Plains regions, while drier conditions lead to more skillful forecasts in the Northwest, Northeast, and Southeast (Supplementary Fig. S6).Fig. 4: Forecast skill of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomalies for lead week 3 in the contiguous United States.Left panel: Week 3 RZSM anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) for the testing period 2018-2019 in the contiguous United States. A, B Ensemble model output statistics (EMOS) and GEFSv12 are in the top row, (C, D) the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G, EX29_G) is in the middle row. E, F is the improvement in ACC for the DL_DM_G (EX29_G) relative to EMOS or GEFSv12. Right panel: Proportion of grid cells above ACC thresholds of 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9 for each model.Full size imageWe further investigate the model generalizability over the globe and re-train the models for China and Australia (Fig. 5). Again, we find that the highest skill is obtained with DL-DM_G spatial ACC improvements of 23% (18%) compared to the raw reforecasts for China (Australia) respectively for percentage of grid cells with ACC >0.6. For seasonal variability in China (Supplementary Fig. S7), the highest contribution to overall ACC skill for week leads 3-4 is from SON with average skill across leads (~0.62 ACC), proceeded by DJF (~0.54), MAM (~0.53), and JJA (~0.40). Improvements in skill relative to GEFSv12 display that the Tibetan plateau has no improvements in skill in JJA for weeks 3-4, while the eastern China agricultural region has improved skill during MAM and JJA. Seasonal skill improvements in Australia are primarily contributed from season JJA with averaged week lead 3-4 ACC of ~0.50, proceeded by MAM (~0.40), and similar results between DJF and SON (~0.37) (Supplemental Fig. S8).Fig. 5: Forecast skill of root zone soil moisture (RZSM) anomalies for lead week 3 in China and Australia.(Left panel) Week 3 RZSM Anomaly correlation coefficient (ACC) for testing years 2018-2019 in (A, C, E) China and (B, D, F) Australia. GEFSv12 is in the top row, the combined deep learning and dynamic model experiment 29 trained on GEFSv12 reforecast (DL-DM_G, EX29_G) is in the middle row, and the bottom row is the difference in ACC between EX29_G and GEFSv12. (Right panel) Proportion of grid cells falling above ACC thresholds of 0.4,0.5,0.6,0.7,0.8,0.9 separated by forecast and region.Full size imageWe analyzed the continuous ranked probability score (CRPSS) to determine the extent to which the CRPS of RISE-UNet predictions were improved relative to raw forecasts (Supplementary Fig. S9). We identified that over CONUS, the CRPSS of DL-DM_G and DL-DM_E were improved over the entire region, with the Central, Northern High Plains, and Eastern coastal regions showing the highest improvements. In China, DL-DM models have CRPSS >0 in many regions except for the Central and Northwest, indicating that raw forecasts have a better CRPS in these regions. In Australia, DL-DM models also have CRPSS >0 in the Western and Eastern portions of the continent, but coastal regions indicate the CRPS of the raw dynamic forecasts is better relative to RISE-UNet.Predictability of dry extremesFor dry weekly RZSM anomalies below the 20th percentile, DL-DM_G is more skillful than raw reforecast based on true positive rate for weekly leads 4-5, false positive rate at leads 3 & 5, and Gilbert skill score at leads 3-4 (Supplementary Fig. S10). The DL-DM_G outperforms GEFSv12 and ECMWF forecasts in the Central and Western United States for the true positive rate, while ECMWF performed well in the Southeast United States, and GEFSv12 performed well only in a few areas in the West (Supplementary Fig. S11). While the models were trained using large samples from 2000–2015, it is worth noting that the sample size was small (n = 104) during the testing period (i.e., dry weekly RZSM anomalies below the 20th percentile from 2018-2019). A longer DM reforecast archive can improve the robustness of the evaluations. In addition, when comparing the difference between the predicted and observed (reanalysis) percentiles, DL-DM_G generally shows a smaller percentile difference in the Western United States, albeit a slight dry bias (Supplemental Fig. S12). ECMWF has a dry bias in the Southeast United States and a wet bias in certain locations in the Central and West, and GEFSv12 has both positive and negative percentile differences scattered in the South and West. Raw reforecasts of ECMWF and GEFSv12 and DL-DM_G predictions have a dry bias in the Northwest. Overall, the results indicate that the RISE-UNet generally outperforms dynamic model forecasts for extremes, while the false positives can predominate in certain regions. It improves the reanalysis-driven DL models, while considerably outperforming the state-of-the-art dynamic models GEFSv12 and ECMWF, and postprocessed bias-corrected dynamic models (DM-BC_DL, or EMOS). Through 29 model experimental runs, we find that the optimal model for lead weeks 1-2 takes antecedent RZSM and atmospheric reanalysis inputs combined with atmospheric reforecast inputs from dynamic models, while for weeks 3-4 it takes antecedent RZSM reanalysis and recursive RZSM predictions, which are embedded with information from atmospheric reanalysis and dynamic model forecasts from previous weeks. This finding suggests the importance of the first two-week dynamic model forecasts and antecedent soil moisture reanalysis for skillful subseasonal RZSM predictions, as also confirmed by the feature importance analysis based on permutation test and SHAP assessment (Fig. 3; Supplementary Fig. S2). Moreover, as great efforts have been made to develop skillful weather, water, and climate forecasts in operational centers around the world, our results show promise for developing efficient deep learning for skillful subseasonal predictions with relatively small computational resources. Since our hybrid model is concise, it can be efficiently trained and implemented in different regions over the globe for skillful, real-time subseasonal RZSM and drought predictions with up to 1000 realizations generated in < 60 s to robustly quantify epistemic uncertainty. Given the advances achieved by our model for significantly improved subseasonal RZSM forecast of dry extremes, it provides a promising tool that can be further implemented or explored for subseasonal predictions of other climate variables, such as extreme precipitation and temperature, moving beyond a 10-day weather forecast.We acknowledge that GLEAM may exhibit systematic biases relative to in-situ observations. Improving the quality of ground-truth reanalysis could therefore enhance future efforts to accurately predict rapid changes in RZSM and drought. Although we have not directly evaluated GLEAM soil moisture, previous research has conducted this evaluation with in-situ observations, finding a global average correlation of 0.6441. Research in the Tibetan plateau identified an R value of ~0.8 between in-situ measurements and GLEAM, which was higher than GLDAS42, and further evidence of a strong correlation between GLDAS and GLEAM has been identified regarding the direction of soil moisture trends43. An additional constraint is that, while SHAP values help attribute physical meaning to input features and quantify their influence on final RZSM or drought predictions across CONUS (Supplementary Fig. S2), they do not reveal how the model internally learns or integrates these features to generate forecasts. For example, although variables like tmax and z200 exhibit a stronger influence on predictions than others, it remains challenging to understand the underlying mechanisms the model uses to produce nationwide predictions. This limitation can be partially addressed by developing region-specific models that further incorporate physical understanding into data-driven approaches, enabling better interpretation of the underlying mechanisms.Our model is based on the RISE-UNet architecture, which is much concise compared to the current large AI models for global medium-range weather forecasts32,33,36,44. It used CRPSexp as a loss function for optimizing ensemble forecasts, which, to our knowledge, has not yet been incorporated in previous research, while showing superior performance compared to the widely used mean-squared error loss (MSE). For ensemble predictions, the CRPSexp is more intuitive than the MSE loss because of its ability to incorporate both the ensemble mean error as well as the standard deviation, which are integral for estimating forecast calibration. Despite the concise architecture, the RISE-UNet models have achieved significantly higher skill than the current state-of-the-art dynamic models in all the lead times, and skill improvement within the first two weeks is even more notable compared to the current large AI weather forecast models32,33. It is worth noting that the errors of the dynamic models were reduced substantially due to DL postprocessing. The reanalysis-driven DL or combined DL-DM models consistently show significantly higher performance than EMOS or raw dynamic models, suggesting the irreducible random errors from the DM at the subseasonal forecast range (i.e., beyond 2 weeks). Dynamic models GEFSv12 and ECMWF show limited ACC skill for predicting RZSM beyond 2 weeks when looking at regional averages (Fig. 2), but seasonal assessments identified spatiotemporal improvements in skill can be significant (Supplemental Figs. S4, S7, S8). We acknowledge that our sample size is small for the testing set years 2018-2019 (n = 104), and for seasonal evaluation, the sample size reduces to approximately n = 31, which can decrease the predictive potential of the model45. Our overall assessment of DL-DM seasonal skill improvements over raw and bias-corrected models displays which subregions have increased skill and elucidates forecast windows of opportunity which are unaccounted for in operational forecast systems and may assist in the mitigation of rapid-onset drought impacts.Our methodology incorporates the full reforecast ensemble spread rather than the ensemble mean, which increases the sample size by a factor of 11 and has a dual-fold benefit compared to traditional architectures. Including the full spread alleviates the need to train separate models specifically for standard deviation36,46 and can augment the training data size. By utilizing currently available ensemble reforecasts, which can have >100 real-time forecast members, computational burdens can be lightened and less effort invested in calibrating separate models for standard deviation. We find that the reanalysis-driven DL models that used antecedent RZSM always show much higher subseasonal forecast skill than dynamic models. This suggests that SMM plays an important role in subseasonal predictions, and SMM dynamics can be efficiently learned through DL, while not well captured by dynamic models. With additional inputs from lead weeks 1 and 2 of dynamic models, the skill for weeks 3 and 4 is further improved through iterative predictions taking previous lead times, which suggest combining DL and DM would be a promising avenue for developing skillful subseasonal forecasts. While DMs are physically constrained and error growth inhibits forecasts after two weeks, hybrid DL-DM models can identify positive signals where forecasts are correct and learn mapping functions to predict more skillfully. While our model has improved deterministic and probabilistic RZSM skill, physics-informed neural networks may be able to effectively capture and understand SMM dynamics and should be explored further within DL-DM forecasts47. Moreover, note that the predictability of weather and climate events are highly influenced by SMM19,48, therefore, improved subseasonal RZSM predictions may be useful for also improving predictions of other subseasonal phenomenon and deserves further studies.We observed that DL-DM predictions in some regions have low skill, such as in the Mississippi River, Ohio Valley, and Southwest regions within CONUS, which has been identified in previous post-processing research for temperature49. Horat and Lerch (2024) implemented a series of experiments with two different UNet architectures and found these same regions have low skill relative to climatology, regardless of the architecture. Here, we argue that for RISE-UNet, low RZSM autocorrelation can be a primary reason for both low skill within DMs as well as post-processed DMs (Supplementary Fig. S13). In the Mississippi, Ohio Valley, and Southwest regions, anomaly autocorrelation \(({\rho }_{k})\) for lags (k) greater than 21 days have noticeably smaller values, which indicate that previous anomalies are less likely to persist in the future, thus inhibiting predictability based solely on memory. While our research has combined both atmospheric and land surface conditions, which have been shown to increase forecast skill50, we find that combining these features did not adequately increase skill in these regions. A natural extension to this research would be the incorporation of additional predictors which influence precipitation and RZSM variability, including sea-surface temperature or high-frequency modes of variability (e.g., North Atlantic Oscillation, Madden Julian Oscillation)14,16,51. In addition, the global UNet models utilized by Horat and Lerch (2024) contained traditional skip connections between layers, which is different than our implementation of a regional RISE-UNet architecture, which concatenates intermediate predictions between layers. It is currently not known what differences in skill for post-processed reforecasts between a traditional UNet vs. RISE-UNet. We leave this to future research to comprehensively examine ensemble predictions trained with CRPSexp loss to identify if the decreased training cost associated with traditional UNet outweighs potential improvements over RISE-UNet.For CONUS, results of higher ACC, lower CRPS, and high CRPSS demonstrate that the RISE-UNet can increase both deterministic and probabilistic skill relative to raw and bias-corrected models (Fig. 2 and Supplemental Fig. S9). Across CONUS, averaged ACC values at lead times >3 weeks are higher than previous research which assessed multiple subseasonal-to-seasonal forecasts52 and ACC skill in week lead 3 in the Southeast is improved compared to13. RISE-UNet predictions show an increase in TPR for dry anomalies in the South, High Plains, and Western United States (Supplementary Figs. S11), which has been identified previously to be low within GEFSv1213. For lead times < 2 weeks, RISE-UNet has much improved deterministic skill across eastern China when compared to research models within the Subseasonal-to-Seasonal database53. Predictions are also improved for the western and southeastern Australia regions, as well as southeast and west China, when compared to the Norwegian Climate Prediction Model54, although a direct assessment is limited due to their research computing monthly average RZSM predictions. Within China, the CRPSS is greater than 0 across the majority of the land mass while in Australia, it is generally restricted to the Southeast coast and inland regions. For these regions with CRPSS < 0, it is notable that RZSM autocorrelation diminishes rapidly after 14 days (results not displayed). Based on spatial variations in seasonal skill13, which are also identified in our research, additional deep learning methods may need to account for different predictors being more impactful at different times of year. The RISE-UNet is trained on all available data, and the model has no explicit awareness of seasonality; therefore, to more effectively capture subregion variability, season-specific weighted predictors may assist in more effectively capturing dynamical relationships which influence RZSM variability.ECMWF and GEFSv12 subseasonal forecasts are not reliant on assimilated RZSM data during initialization, which allows them to work efficiently within an operational setting. This can be a disadvantage due to the importance of accurate land surface initializations, which are required for skillful forecasts of temperature and precipitation19. As future models are developed and data assimilation procedures implemented into land surface model initializations, we can expect that the quality of the dynamic model forecast will increase, and further post-processing using the RISE-UNet can subsequently correct model biases. Alternatively, future research can incorporate hydrological models which include a more extensive set of land surface parameterizations which account for land surface fluxes such as Noah-MP55,56. Additional constraints which may impact operational performance include using lagged RZSM from reanalysis which may not be directly available on a weekly basis due to data assimilation and quality control procedures. This can be circumvented by incorporating near real-time soil moisture data, such as from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Short-term Prediction and Transition Center.Finally, we should note several limitations of this study and potential future works. First, we chose GLEAM RZSM as our primary observational reference due to its moderate-to-high correlation with in-situ RZSM observations and eddy covariance towers across the globe41, but there are still discrepancies13. There is an imperative need to develop improved, accurate soil moisture estimations through improved land surface modeling and satellite remote sensing57. Second, our models did not account for large-scale teleconnections. While previous studies show that long-term predictability of soil moisture dynamics is mainly due to SMM, incorporating large-scale drivers could improve soil moisture predictability within the subseasonal timescale58. Moreover, with explainable DL, new sources of subseasonal predictability at the large scale could be potentially revealed. Third, SHAP values were constructed across CONUS, which limits a comprehensive understanding of how each feature influences the final prediction due to heterogeneity across the region. A more through investigation into smaller regions could more easily isolate the relative influence and interpretation of each feature. Lastly, despite the significant improvement achieved by our model compared to the current state-of-the-art dynamic models, the prediction of extreme events still needs further improvement. Since DL inherently suffers from extrapolation issues59, it will be a great challenge to predict unprecedented extreme events as future climate pattern shifts. Continuous efforts are needed to improve dynamic models’ parameterizations, resolutions, initializations, and physics, and further couple with a DL model to harness the strength of both modeling approaches.MethodsReanalysis dataWe obtained daily soil moisture from December 1999 - February 2020 for surface (0–10 cm) and rooting-zone (10–100 cm) and created a weighted average of surface and rooting-zone for 0–100 cm hereafter referred to as root-zone soil moisture (RZSM) from the Global Land Evapotranspiration Amsterdam Model (GLEAM v3.8a) data product. The weighted average was computed as the sum of each variable, which was multiplied by a scaling factor associated with depth with based on \({{RZSM}}_{{weighted}}=\tfrac{{surface}*10{cm}}{100{cm}}+\tfrac{{rooting}-{zone}*90{cm}}{100{cm}}\). GLEAM is a set of algorithms which estimates terrestrial evaporation, surface- and root-zone soil moisture, and hydraulic fluxes using satellite observations41,60. Soil moisture is modeled using both Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity and European Space Agency Climate Change Initiative satellites and assimilated with Noah Global Land Data Assimilation System reanalysis with data available globally at a spatial resolution of 0.25 x 0.25°. Data was bilinearly interpolated to a horizontal resolution of 0.5° and a seven-day rolling mean was applied to each grid cell. Seasonal anomalies for each day and grid cell were created by subtracting the seasonal mean computed between 2000–2015 from each observation date, excluding the validation or testing period. Seasons are defined according to conventional categories of DJF (December, January, February), MAM (March, April, May), JJA (June, July, August), SON (September, October, November). Seasonal distributions were created by grouping observations within the same calendar season. The seasonal mean was then subtracted to isolate anomalies.We retrieved hourly data for 2 m dewpoint temperature, 2 m maximum temperature (Tmax), 2 m minimum temperature (Tmin), precipitable water (pwat), surface pressure, and 200 hPa geopotential height (z200) from the fifth generation of European ReAnalysis (ERA5) between October 1999 - February 2020. ERA5 has been shown to be superior to Modern Era Retrospective Analysis version 2 over North America and Europe for convective processes, boundary layer height, temperature, and cloud cover61,62,63. We computed the difference between Tmax and Tmin, hereafter referred to as ∆tmp, and computed 2 m specific humidity (spfh) using dewpoint and surface pressure64. The rationale for including ∆tmp is that radiation resolving processes within models are less well resolved within low resolution models, which can be impacted by poor cloud representation, which impacts radiation feedbacks65. ∆tmp considers the diurnal temperature difference and a higher/lower temperature difference over land explicitly implies that there was either less/more cloud coverage that day or a frontal storm system occurred which can either increase or decrease ∆tmp. For volumetric soil water, the top 3 layers were weighted and summed by the same procedure as GLEAM RZSM. We bilinearly interpolated all variables to a horizontal resolution of 0.5°, applied a seven-day rolling mean to each grid cell, and constructed seasonal anomalies identically to GLEAM.For each study region, including the contiguous United States (CONUS), China, and Australia, data was subset according to the specific latitude and longitude bounding box coordinates listed in Supplementary Table S5.Retrospective forecast (reforecast) from dynamic modelsWe used subseasonal forecasts of weekly leads 1 to 5 from the Global Ensemble Forecast version 12 (GEFSv12) and subseasonal-to-seasonal European Center for Medium Range Weather Forecasting (S2S ECMWF) models reforecast archive. Within this study, we refer to the S2S ECMWF as ECMWF. The GEFSv12 model was initialized using GEFSv12-reanalysis, and the forecasts were generated by coupling the GFSv15.1 AGCM with Noah LSM to produce a global 11-member ensemble each Wednesday with a lead time of 35 days66. The first ensemble realization is the control forecast, while the remaining 10 realizations are stochastically perturbed. While the GEFSv12 reforecast data is available for 2020–2022 in a different repository, initializations during this period are produced with a different model version. For consistency, we did not incorporate that period into this study and only considered the period of 2000–2019. The first ten days of the GEFSv12-reforecast are provided on a spatial resolution of 0.25° and temporal steps of three hours, while the last twenty-five days are provided at a spatial resolution of 0.50° and temporal steps of six hours. We downloaded 1043 initializations between the years 2000–2019 for Tmax, Tmin, z200, spfh, and RZSM. For Tmax and Tmin, we retrieved only the maximum and minimum values for each day, respectively and computed ∆tmp. For all other variables, we obtained a daily mean by averaging all 3- or 6-hourly leads for each day. For RZSM, we computed the weighted average of soil moisture layer depths 0–10 cm, 10–40 cm, 40–100 cm and obtained the daily mean for the final depth of 0–100 cm. RZSM weighting was constructed similarly to GLEAM, where the scaling factor was computed according to the layer depth in cm. For all ECMWF and GEFSv12 predictors, we retain the model using the entire 11-ensemble member forecast. For each lead time, seasonal distributions were created by grouping forecasts whose lead dates fell within the same calendar season. The seasonal mean was then subtracted to isolate anomalies, which are used as model inputs.The operational ECMWF real-time extended range forecasts are a set of global 51-member ensembles produced twice weekly (Monday and Thursday) with a lead time of 45 days for years 2015-present. For our experiment, we utilized the ECMWF retrospective forecasts (reforecasts), which use the same model version and configuration of the ECMWF real-time forecast but are initialized with past known conditions from ERA5 and are available at 1.5° resolution with a smaller set of 11 ensemble members67. These 11-member ensembles are produced for the previous 20 years for the same calendar date when the real-time forecast is produced and are hereafter referred to as ECMWF reforecast. ECMWF reforecast is initialized with assimilated observational data, and the predictions are made with the coupled Integrated Forecasting System (IFS) for atmospheric physics and the Hydrology Tiled ECMWF Scheme for Surface Exchanges over Land (HTESSEL) for land surface dynamics. The first ensemble realization is the control forecast, while the remaining 10 realizations are stochastically perturbed. We subset the data to only include the exact same 1043 initialization dates as GEFSv12 and consider the first 35 days lead time. Within the ECMWF data portal, atmospheric variables provided are not identical to GEFSv12; therefore, we incorporate daily averaged 2 m mean temperature (Tmean), pwat, 2 m dewpoint temperature (Tdew), and 0–100 cm RZSM. RZSM was conservatively interpolated to 0.5° resolution because bilinear interpolation produces null artifacts along coastlines due to interpolation with missing values associated with oceans. Atmospheric variables were bilinearly interpolated to 0.5° resolution, and we computed anomalies for all variables identically to GEFSv12.ECMWF and GEFSv12 subseasonal reforecasts have different initialization dates, which can influence a direct comparison between models. To align ECMWF and GEFSv12 reforecasts, we matched lead times based on valid forecast dates, rather than attempting to align initialization dates. For example, an ECMWF reforecast initialized on Monday, Dec 2, 2019 (and its 20-year hindcast ensemble) would be compared against a GEFSv12 reforecast initialized on Dec 2, 2019, even if ECMWF did not produce a forecast on every intervening day. We verified that this approach preserves forecast lead equivalency (e.g., week-3 lead = days 15–21), and we tested sensitivity to potential day-of-week effects, which showed negligible differences in skill scores across the majority of grid cells across CONUS. The process is straightforward and creates a new ECMWF file with a 43-day forecast with the first lead date matching the first lead date from GEFSv12. While short-lead forecasts are sensitive to initialization timing due to the strong influence of initial conditions, at longer leads (e.g., week-4), the marginal degradation in skill from a two-day difference in initialization date is negligible. Therefore, aligning forecast periods across GEFSv12 and ECMWF, even with minor mismatches in start dates, remains a reasonable approximation for comparative skill analysis. While baseline subseasonal forecast skill from dynamic models alone tends to decline significantly beyond two weeks, our results show that hybrid approaches, combining early-lead dynamic forecasts and antecedent soil moisture states within deep learning models, can substantially improve predictability at weeks 3–5.The selection of GEFSv12 and ECMWF as our two primary models is specifically due to these models providing RZSM data at lower depths (0-1 m), which can be directly compared with reanalysis products. This depth has been shown in previous literature to encompass 11 different crops in temperature regions, which are highly relevant within agriculture and can be susceptible to droughts which occur within the subseasonal timescale13,68. In addition, other models within the SubX project (RSMAS, GMAO, NRL, ECCC) do not provide soil moisture data at unified depths; specifically, these models have a variable rooting depth between 1.5–3 m, which can vary between models16. We did not identify specific models within the S2S project, aside from ECMWF, which may have similar soil moisture depths, although some of these models may be suitable for root-zone drought forecasting and monitoring67.Data pre-processingFeature (variable) scaling is necessary for statistical and DL models because features with different scales decrease model flexibility by forcing the model to simply reduce the error from the feature with the highest scale difference relative to the predicted output. This reduction in error does not imply an increase in testing performance because that feature may not be highly associated with the final prediction. We split the data into training (years 2000–2015), validation (2016-2017), and testing (2018-2019). For each variable, seasonal anomalies were scaled using min-max normalization, where the minimum and maximum values were obtained over the entire spatial domain from only the training period, with the following equation \({x^{\prime}}_{{ijk}}=[{x}_{{ijk}}-\min ({x}_{i})]/\,[\max ({x}_{i})-\min ({x}_{i})]\). With \({x}_{{ijk}}\) and \({x^{\prime} }_{{ijk}}\) being the unscaled and scaled feature value, respectively, for lead i, latitude j, and longitude k. All values will be within the range 0-1. For RZSM, ocean and water bodies have no values and are masked with a value of zero prior to training the model.To prepare input for the RISE-UNet models (described in the next section), we stack the observations and reforecast predictors (see Supplementary Table S1) according to the initialized date and the ensemble realization to produce a final input shape during training of (9185 samples, 48 latitude grid cells, 96 longitude grid cells, N channel). For clarification, each channel is a single predictor variable for a single lead or lag (e.g., GLEAM RZSM inputs from six lag weeks will be six different channels). For a more in-depth understanding of the creation of lagged observations, see Supplementary Table S6. The 9185 samples were obtained by taking each initialization and ensemble realization in the training period and transforming into a lower-dimensional latent feature space (835 initializations x 11 ensemble realizations = 9185 total samples). N channels is dependent upon the experiment number found in Supplementary Table S1. The verification and testing data were stacked similarly with sizes (1144 samples, 48 latitude grid cells, 96 longitude grid cells, N channels).Deep learning architecture and experiment setupModel architectureA climate variable at each time step can be viewed as a two-dimensional image. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are powerful for learning complex functional relationships across spatial dimensions and covariate features among different images. The UNet architecture based on CNN69 is a deep neural network model containing a symmetric encoding-decoding structure that learns both low- and high-level feature abstractions between covariates and across spatial regions. Previous studies have used UNet architectures to bias correct and post-process both short- and long-lead NWP ensemble forecasts of temperature, geopotential height, and precipitation, with results indicating better performance than raw forecasts for various leads and regions36,46,70. A new variant of the UNet is the UNet + +3, which contains a series of nested and dense skip connections connecting each encoder-decoder block with previous blocks across the same spatial dimensions [Fig. 1B]71. This nested architecture has benefits over traditional UNet, which can suffer from information loss as downsampling occurs and is overcome through multiple nested skip connections. We modified the original UNet + +3 architecture by adding inception, residual, and squeeze-and-excitation72 (SE) blocks to increase the model’s spatial relation understanding and feature space representation. The new model architecture is named as residual inception squeeze-and-excitation (RISE) UNet + +, hereafter referred to as RISE-UNet (Fig. 1). For each Inception operator block, we include four parallel convolutional filters using kernel sizes of 3 × 3, 5 × 5, 7 × 7, and max pooling layer 5 × 5 and filter sizes of [32,64,128,256] for the 1st through 4th encoder backbone respectively. After each convolution, batch normalization (BN) is applied, followed by the rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation, and we pass another 1 × 1 convolution kernel with the same number of previous filters, followed by BN. We concatenate the four parallel convolution blocks, add the original input as a residual connection to reduce diminishing gradients and finally apply a SE block with sigmoid activation function to the summed residual/inception block in order to weight inter-channel features. Dropout layers are applied within each convolutional block to act as a regularization technique to prevent overfitting and improve generalization. Between 10–25% of the two-dimensional layers are randomly dropped during the training process, which creates stochastic predictions during model inference over the testing period. We train the model individually (and recursively for selected experiments) for weekly leads 1–5. This set of functions allows the model to adjust model weights, which both decrease the error and increase the spread of the forecast, thereby retaining stochasticity similar to that of physically-based dynamic models.Weather and climate ensemble forecast systems employ various perturbation methods to account for uncertainty in initial conditions and allow for the quantification of uncertainties due to errors in initial conditions, model formulation, and physical parameterizations74,75,76,77. More specifically, when using a singular realization contrived from assimilated observations and processed through a physically-based land and atmospheric model, uncertainty can be imparted from instrument calibration error or model structural errors associated with parameterizations of complex processes. Small errors within initial conditions have been observed to rapidly amplify in weather forecasting and restrict the intrinsic predictability limit of forecast systems78; therefore, perturbation methods allow for inclusion of a wider range of plausible initial conditions to evaluate uncertainty in ensemble forecasts through sensitivity experiments and probabilistic evaluations. The RISE-UNet DL architecture accepts an ensemble of stochastically generated initial conditions and passes these inputs through a series of operators (convolution kernels, squeeze-and-excitation, and max-pooling), non-linear activation functions (ReLU and sigmoid), and dropout layers to produce stochastic ensemble forecasts for each lead week. The CRPSexp loss function is computed over each set of 11 ensemble members generated from the RISE-UNet, which allows for gradient-based model weight adjustments based on the aggregated loss.Experimental setupTo determine the optimal model and understand what impacts the forecast skill, we constructed a series of experiments (Supplemental Table S1) in which the RISE-UNet DL model only takes historical reanalysis (DL), only dynamic model (DM) reforecast (DM-BC_DL), or combined reanalysis and dynamic model (DM) reforecasts (DL-DM) as inputs to predict weekly RZSM anomalies for leads 1–5. For the DL and DL-DM scenarios, a forecast is made by recursively applying RISE-UNet to the previous prediction to produce a prediction at successive lead weeks 2–5 (N). For further clarification, weekly lag/lead inputs have been computed by the following pre-processing pipeline: apply a 7-day rolling mean, compute seasonal anomaly, and perform min-max standardization. For example, Week lag 1 of reanalysis represents the antecedent information from the day before the forecast initialization date through the previous week. Specifically, the scenario DM-BC_DL includes experiments EX0 and EX13, which bias-correct DM forecasts using reanalysis, where EX0 uses all previous reforecast weeks as input predictors, while EX13 only includes the current week (single predictor). The scenario DL includes only lagged reanalysis as inputs, with EX14-EX17 containing atmospheric variables and RZSM, while EX22-EX25 includes only RZSM. DL-DM is the combined model including both lagged reanalysis and DM reforecasts, which includes EX1-EX4, EX5-EX8, EX9-EX12, EX27-EX28, and EX29. EX1-EX4 includes atmosphere and RZSM from reanalysis, as well as recursively predicted RZSM inputs from the previous time step. Recursively predicted inputs are the predictions of the previous lead weeks from the DL-DM model, which are used to predict the next lead week. EX9-EX12 is identical to EX1-EX4 with the exception of including DM RZSM for week (N) as an input. EX5-EX8 includes only RZSM reanalysis and DM RZSM for week (N) as inputs, and EX18-EX21 further include recursively predicted RZSM. EX27-EX28 are identical to EX9-EX10, with the exception of including DM reforecast atmospheric inputs up to lead week two. The setup of experiments in this manner allows for a robust assessment of each set of inputs on forecast skill79.Feature importance evaluationPermutation testTo determine the impact of each input variable on model skill in the testing dataset (2018-2019), we conducted a permutation test on each input individually for each experimental run. The order of operations for the permutation test for each experimental run goes as follows: First, a single input variable was selected (e.g., RZSM observation week lag 1) and random Gaussian noise was added, with mean and standard deviation from training data input statistics. Second, the input data was transformed via min-max normalization based on the new minimum and maximum. Third, with only a single input transformed and all other inputs identical, the combined inputs were fed into the RISE-UNet pre-trained model, and 11 ensemble predictions were made for each initialization in the testing period. Finally, the ensemble mean was computed and MAE evaluated.SHapley additive exPlanations (SHAP)To further interpret the predictions of our deep learning model, we employed SHAP, which is a unified framework that attributes a prediction to input features based on cooperative game theory80,81. SHAP assigns each feature an importance value for a particular prediction by estimating the contribution of each feature to the model output. SHAP values are grounded in cooperative game theory and satisfy the property of additive feature attribution,$$f\left(x\right)=\,{{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{0}+\,\mathop{\sum }_{i=1}^{M}{{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}$$
                    (4)
                where \(f\left(x\right)\) is the model prediction for input \(x\), \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{0}\) is the expected model output, and \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\) denotes the SHAP value corresponding to the input feature i. To efficiently compute SHAP values, we used the Gradient Explainer, which estimates SHAP values based on the model’s gradients with respect to its inputs, integrated along a straight-line path from a baseline input to the actual input and computed as,$${{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\approx ({x}_{i}-{\acute{x}}_{i})\cdot {\int }_{\alpha=0}^{1}\frac{\partial f(\acute{x}+\alpha \left(x-\acute{x}\right))}{\partial {x}_{i}}d\alpha$$
                    (5)
                where \(x\)′ is a baseline input and \(\frac{\partial f}{\partial {x}_{i}}\) is the gradient of the model output with respect to the input feature \({x}_{i}\). This formulation captures how the model’s prediction changes as the input transitions from the baseline \({x}_{i}\) to the actual value \(x\). Interpreting these results involves examining both the magnitude and sign of each \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\) with larger absolute values denoting greater influence on the final prediction, while the sign indicates whether the feature pushes the prediction higher (positive \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\)) or lower (negative \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{i}\)) relative to the baseline prediction \({{{{\rm{\varphi }}}}}_{0}\). Therefore, SHAP Gradient Explainer shows the relative influence of each predictor on the final output and identifies how small or large changes in the feature influence the final output, mimicking the methods of a sensitivity test. For computation, we randomly selected 500 background samples from the training dataset to evaluate SHAP values over the testing dataset.Ensemble model outputs statistics (EMOS)As a comparison, DM is also bias-corrected using ensemble model output statistics (DM-BC_EMOS). EMOS is a parametric statistical post-processing technique which incorporates NWP ensemble predictions and fits a predictive model to minimize the continuous ranked probability score (CRPS)82. For every observation, EMOS conducts multiple linear regression to compute a predictive probability density function (PDF). Let Xi, …, Xn indicate N ensemble forecasts for a univariate continuous, positive-defined predicted variable \(Y\). Then \(Y=a+{b}_{1}{X}_{1}+\ldots {+b}_{n}{X}_{n}+\varepsilon\) where the a, b1, …, bn are the regression coefficients and \(\varepsilon\) is the error term which averages to zero. The variance of \(\varepsilon\) is modeled as a linear function of the ensemble spread, \({Var}\left(\varepsilon \right)=c+d{S}^{2}\) where S2 is the ensemble variance, and c and d are non-negative coefficients. These terms yield the Gaussian predictive distribution \(N\left(a+{b}_{1}{X}_{1}+\ldots {+b}_{n}{X}_{n},{c}+d{S}^{2}\right)\) whose mean forms a bias-corrected weighted average of the ensemble forecasts, and whose variance depends linearly on the ensemble variance. With the predictive PDF, ensemble predictions can be made of any size.For each weekly lead and grid cell, an EMOS model was trained on the 11-member GEFSv12 anomaly RZSM ensemble. We evaluated four different EMOS modeling schemes including training on data from: a) only dates that were 12 weeks before the predicted date with data from only the training period (2000–2015) [192 initialization dates], b) only dates +/− 12 weeks from the predicted date in the training period [384 initialization dates], c) only dates that were 12 weeks before the predicted date with data from only the training and validation period (2000-2017) [216 initialization dates], d) only dates +/− 12 weeks from the predicted date in the training and validation period [432 initialization dates]. The purpose of these four different schemes allows for a more robust metric comparison from models trained on different sample sizes (deep learning training = 835 initialization dates vs. EMOS training = ~192-432 initialization dates), and allows for an EMOS inter-model comparison. Training EMOS on all 835 initializations produced highly unskillful predictions (results not displayed). Models were evaluated over the testing period (2018-2019). More information on each EMOS experiment can be found in Supplementary Table S4).Evaluation metricsFor all evaluation metrics, forecast skill results are averaged over forecasts made at weekly intervals across the entire calendar year for the two-year testing period 2018-2019. We evaluate probabilistic forecast skill with the CRPS and continuous ranked probability skill score (CRPSS), and deterministic skill with the Anomaly Correlation Coefficient (ACC). The CRPS measures the performance ensemble forecasts relative to observations by computing the forecast predictive cumulative distribution function (CDF) calculating the integral of the squared difference between the CDF and the observation, which is considered a step function. CRPS is concerned with the accuracy and spread of the forecasts, rather than an individual point estimate, with lower CRPS values indicate greater skill and a value of 0 indicates a perfect prediction model. CRPS is defined as follows, \({CRPS}\left(F,y\right)=\,{\int }_{-\infty }^{+\infty }{(F\left(x\right)-{1}_{\left\{x > y\right\}})}^{2}{dx}\) where F(x) is the predicted CDF, 1 is the Heaviside step function, where values of observation (x) that are greater than prediction (y) are given a value of 1 and y < x is given a value of 0. The CRPS was computed for each grid cell and averaged over all initialization dates within the testing period (2018-2019).The CRPSS compares the CRPS of the ensemble forecast to that of a reference forecast to determine whether the ensemble spread is a useful measure of forecasting uncertainty and this metric was computed with the Python package83. The CRPSS is formally defined as \({CRPSS}=1-\,\frac{{{CRPS}}_{{RISE}-{UNet}}}{{{CRPS}}_{{reference}}}\), where CRPSreference represents the CRPS of the raw forecast (GEFSv12 or ECMWF), and CRPSRISE-UNet is the CRPS of the deep learning model forecast. CRPSS values greater than 0 indicate that the RISE-UNet forecast is more skillful than the raw forecast, and values less than 0 indicate RISE-UNet is less skillful, with the range of CRPSS being (-\(\infty\),1].The ACC describes the correlation between a forecast anomaly relative to forecast climatology and a verifying observation anomaly relative to observation climatology. ACC indicates the strength of association for both direction and magnitude of forecasts relative to observations, with values falling between − 1.0 and 1.0. \({ACC}=\frac{\mathop{\sum }_{m=1}^{M}({f}_{m}-\bar{f})({o}_{m}-\bar{o})}{{\left[\mathop{\sum }_{m=1}^{M}{\left({f}_{m}-\bar{f}\right)}^{2}\mathop{\sum }_{m=1}^{M}{\left({o}_{m}-\bar{o}\right)}^{2}\right]}^{1/2}}\) where M is the total number of time samples, fm is the forecast, \(\bar{f}\) is the forecast climatology, om is the observation, and \(\bar{o}\) is the observation climatology. ACC values approaching 1.0 indicate strong positive agreement where forecasts have value, ACC values >0.6 indicate synoptic prediction skill for large weather patterns, ACC values approaching 0.5 indicate the forecast errors are similar to errors from a forecast of the climatological average, and ACC values around 0 indicate the forecast has no value84. We calculated the ACC using the mean of all ensemble members within the testing period 2018-2019 and averaged the results by region.Categorical (binary) accuracy was assessed for anomalies falling below the 20th percentile using the True positive rate (TPR), False positive rate (FPR), and Gilbert skill score (GSS). Forecasts were evaluated using a contingency table in which each forecast lead time is verified against observations from the same date where the random variable true positive (TP) indicates that forecast and observation both classified anomalies being below the 20th percentile, false positive (FP) when the forecast predicted anomalies below the 20th percentile but the observation did not, false negative (FN) when the forecast predicted anomalies above the 20th percentile when observations were above the 20th percentile, and true negative (TN) when both forecast and observations were above the 20th percentile13. The true positive rate (TPR), also known as sensitivity, assesses the percentage of correct forecast predictions compared to all predicted events, including events that did not occur in observations85. \({{TPR}}_{{jk}}=\frac{\sum {{TP}}_{{jk}}}{\sum {{TP}}_{{jk}}+\sum {{FN}}_{{jk}}}\) where j,k are the respective grid cell and TPR values range from 0–100% where 100% indicates that all anomalies below the 20th percentile were correctly classified. We calculated TPR for each grid cell and averaged the results by region. The false positive rate (FPR)85 assesses the percentage of predictions that were incorrectly classified as positive and is the ratio of incorrectly forecasted events below the 20th percentile to the total number of actual negative events below the 20th percentile \({{FPR}}_{{jk}}=\frac{\sum {{FP}}_{{jk}}}{\sum {{FP}}_{{jk}}+\sum {{TN}}_{{jk}}}\). The Gilbert skill score (GSS)85, also known as the Equitable threat score, measures the fraction of events that were correctly predicted and is adjusted for hits associated with random change and equitability allows scores to be compared more fairly across different regimes \({{GSS}}_{{jk}}=\frac{\sum {{TP}}_{{jk}}-\sum {{TP}}_{{random}}}{\sum {{TP}}_{{jk}}+\sum {{FN}}_{{jk}}+\sum {{FP}}_{{jk}}-{\sum {TP}}_{{random}}}\). TPrandom is the number of TP hits by random chance and is defined as \({{TP}}_{{random}}=\frac{\left(\sum {TP}+\sum {FP}\right){x}\left(\sum {TP}+\sum {FN}\right)}{N}\) where N is the total number of observation events. Values for the GSS fall within the range − 1/3 to +1 with values of 0 indicating no skill and values of 1 indicating perfect skill.The Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) is commonly used to measure the similarity between a set of images and provides information on three image components, including luminance, contrast, and structure86. Luminance \(({\mu }_{x})\) is the average of all pixel values \({\mu }_{x}=\frac{1}{N}\mathop{\sum }_{i=1}^{N}{x}_{i}\) and captures the brightness and intensity of pixel values N, contrast \(({\sigma }_{x})\) is the standard deviation of all pixel values \({\sigma }_{x}={\left(\frac{1}{N-1}\mathop{\sum }_{i=1}^{N}{({x}_{i}-{\mu }_{x})}^{2}\right)}^{1/2}\) and refers to the difference in intensity between nearby pixels, and structure \(({s}_{x})\) is the unit-normalized image \(({s}_{x})=\frac{x-{\mu }_{x}}{{\sigma }_{{x}}}\). For each of these components, comparison functions are applied to the two images and SSIM evaluated. SSIM values lie within the range -1.0 and 1.0, with values of 1.0 indicating identically similar images, values of 0 indicating different images, and values approaching − 1.0 indicating complete dissimilarity. Since SSIM is based on visible structures in the image, it measures the perceptual difference between two similar images, but not which one has higher accuracy.The Kling-Gupta Efficiency (KGE) is a calibration metric used to quantify goodness-of-fit of hydrological simulations87. The KGE metric is an alternative to the Nash-Sutcliffe Efficiency (NSE) and is designed to address some of its limitations, particularly in balancing the bias, variability, and correlation of the simulated data with observed data. \({KGE}=1-\sqrt{{\left(r-1\right)}^{2}+{\left(\beta -1\right)}^{2}+{\left(\gamma -1\right)}^{2}}\). It ranges from -∞ to 1 and is computed as the sum of three components, including correlation (r), bias ratio (β), and variability ratio (γ). Pearson linear correlation (r) measure the linear correlation between simulated and observed samples, β represents the ratio of the means of the simulated and observed data \(\beta=\,\frac{{\mu }_{{simulated}}}{{\mu }_{{observed}}}\), and γ measure the ratio of the standard deviations of the simulated and observed data \(\gamma=\,\frac{{\sigma }_{{simulated}}}{{\sigma }_{{observed}}}\). KGE values approaching 1 indicate near-perfect agreement between the simulated and observed data and values approaching -∞ indicate very poor model performance.

Published: 11 August 2025

Managing climate impacts—an analysis of adaptation funding in German cities and districts
                    Marlene Kammerer1,2,3 & Ulrike Zeigermann4,5,6

npj Climate Action

volume 4, Article number: 76 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change adaptationClimate-change mitigationClimate-change policyEnvironmental social sciencesGovernanceGovernmentPolitics

AbstractWith accelerating climate change, local governments must enhance adaptation efforts. Germany’s federal adaptation funding scheme (DAS) supports municipalities in developing adaptation strategies, yet disparities in funding distribution remain. This study analyses DAS adaptation funding across 400 German cities and districts using multilevel regression models. Findings reveal that urban areas receive more funding, influenced by higher education levels, income, and political support, and prior climate mitigation funding. In contrast, the sensitivity dimension of climate vulnerability shows weak correlations with funding allocation. These results highlight an urban-rural divide in climate adaptation financing and emphasize the role of socioeconomic and political factors in shaping local climate action. By addressing gaps in adaptation policy implementation, this study contributes to the understanding of climate governance and provides insights for improving the equitable distribution of adaptation funding.
